title: Ashe Arrow Visual/Hitbox is Still Extremely Misleading

embed.description: Imgur: The most awesome images on the Internet.

body:
Problems:

1. The arrow hitbox is significantly wider than its animation.
2. The arrow hitbox does not begin at the point of the arrow. It often appears that the point completely misses, yet the center of the body hits someone

I do not feel that the arrow hitbox is actually too big as far as the balance goes. It's just the arrow visual often looks like it has missed, the point goes past, the it hits you from the side of the body of the arrow as you sidestep. But please make the arrow head like wider or something so that **it actually looks like it hit the things it stuns**

replies.body:
Look at a champions shadow when you consider if an ability should land or not. The camera angle can be weird and mess with the 2d plane the game decides these things based on.

The shadow usually represents what a champion hitbox actually is but not always. If you do Lee's dance animation he will jump all over but his shadow will stay where his hitbox actually is. The same happens with some champions walk animations to a lesser extent.

Also the spectator client has some bugs in it with showing what happened in the game sometimes.
Needs more upvotes

Nah the hitbox doesn't match the visual at all. On your screen it can appear that you side stepped it, and you may still get hooked. 

Thresh hook, blitz hook, morgana Q, lux Q (and ult) and leblanc tether all need their visuals updated to better reflect the width of their hit boxes.

After digging around forums, reddit and other assorted boards and webpages, I've come to two conclusions.

One: Riot has never answered any questions about hitbox inconsistancies, as far as I can tell, which suggests that they simple don't care how borked are in some cases
Two: In my search, I found that hitboxes seem to extend into the shadow of the champ, for reasons unknown, which may illuminate some of what happened here.

I don't think they extend to the shadow, I think like someone said earlier they are just above it. So when you character model runs and leans forward, the hitbox is slightly behind them. Which explains why when you sidestep and are running away it clips your hitbox but not your character model

but even so, when you look at fakers shadow and the arrow, you can pretty clearly draw a line separating them. so the arrow is misleading too

You do seem to have a point there, though I'd say the hitbox of the arrow in this instance is the extent of the blue haze surrounding the arrow. As for the hitbox being in the shadow, my source is thus:
http://www.team-dignitas.net/articles/blogs/League-of-Legends/6419/League-of-Legends-A-Game-of-Hitboxes-Skillshots-and-Dodging
It's an older set of examples, but I've found no data that Riot has changed anything since then.
